summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney, Bobbi C. Sternheim, to Judge Alison J. Nathan, renewing a request for the early release of potential juror names to counsel in Maxwell's criminal trial. The letter argues that withholding names until voir dire would impede necessary background research and violate Maxwell's right to a fair and impartial jury, citing legal precedents and bar association opinions.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case S2 20 Cr. 330 (AJN), for whom her attorney is requesting juror name disclosure to ensure a fair trial.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell who authored and signed the letter to Judge Nathan, arguing for the release of juror names and citing her prior appointment as juror counsel in the Parse/Daugerdas case.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, to whom the request for juror name disclosure is addressed.

persons.name: Catherine M. Conrad
persons.context: Referred to as Juror No. 1 in the Parse/Daugerdas case, who lied during voir dire, leading to a new trial and vacated conviction, cited as an example of why juror background research is critical.

persons.name: William H. Pauley III
persons.context: Judge in the Parse/Daugerdas case who granted a new trial after discovering juror misconduct and appointed Bobbi C. Sternheim to represent the juror.

persons.name: Parse
persons.context: A defendant in the United States v. Daugerdas financial fraud case whose conviction was vacated due to juror Catherine Conrad's falsehoods during voir dire.

persons.name: Norman K. Moon
persons.context: Judge in the Western District of Virginia who issued an order in Sines v. Kessler allowing designated persons access to juror questionnaires, cited as a precedent.

persons.name: Richard Spencer
persons.context: A pro se defendant described as a prominent white supremacist in the Sines v. Kessler case, who was granted access to juror names and questionnaires.

persons.name: Christopher Cantwell
persons.context: A pro se defendant described as a neo-Nazi in the Sines v. Kessler case, who was granted access to juror names and questionnaires.

connections.description: Sternheim is the defense attorney representing Maxwell in her criminal case, as evidenced by the letter arguing for her client's right to a fair jury.
Judge Pauley appointed Sternheim to represent juror Catherine Conrad during the post-conviction evidentiary hearing in the Parse/Daugerdas case.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case, as indicated in the case caption and the letter's address.
Conrad was a juror in Parse's trial whose falsehoods during voir dire led to the vacating of Parse's conviction.

events.title: Pre-trial Teleconference
events.description: A teleconference in the Maxwell case where the court discussed juror questionnaire procedures, leading to defense counsel's understanding that juror names would be provided.

events.title: Sines v. Kessler Order on Juror Access
events.description: Judge Norman K. Moon issued an order amending pretrial procedures to allow designated persons, including pro se defendants, access to juror questionnaires and names.

events.title: Parse/Daugerdas Post-Conviction Hearing
events.description: Judge Pauley conducted an evidentiary hearing after discovering juror Catherine Conrad lied during voir dire, leading to a new trial for some defendants.

events.title: Second Circuit Ruling in Parse
events.description: The Second Circuit Court of Appeals reversed Judge Pauley's waiver ruling and vacated Parse's conviction, affirming the jury was not impartial.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team is requesting the names of 600 potential jurors be released to counsel upon completion of questionnaires, not at voir dire, to allow for background research.

The defense argues withholding juror names would violate Maxwell's right to a fair and impartial jury and cites the Sines v. Kessler case where juror names were provided even to pro se defendants accused of being white supremacists.
The letter cites the Parse/Daugerdas case where a juror's falsehoods during voir dire led to a vacated conviction, emphasizing the importance of pre-voir dire research.
Multiple bar associations, including the New York City Bar and American Bar Association, are cited as recognizing that internet research on jurors is an expected standard of competent legal practice.
The document is a strategic legal filing aimed at influencing pre-trial procedures in a high-profile criminal case.
